Sky Betting and Gaming and Macmillan Cancer Support are working together to support more people living with and affected by cancer.
The statistics:
	1 in 2 people in the UK will get a cancer diagnosis in their lifetime. 
	1000 people will get diagnosed each day in the UK
	3 million people are living with cancer in the UK today 

Macmillans ambition is to be there for every person living with cancer and provide them with tailored support when they need it most. Being told you have cancer is life-changing, and having the right support can have a huge impact physically, financially and emotionally.  The number of people living with cancer today is nearly 3 million, and this is set to rise to over 5 million by 2040.  Sky Betting and Gamings support is needed more than ever.

story:
The Nippy Dippers are a group of men from across the Highlands, Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire who will be braving the elements in aid of Macmillan Cancer Support.

Every day in December 2020, the participants will be undertaking cold water exposure through loch or sea swims, ice/cold water baths, cold showers or a splash in any other body of chilly water they can find. Maybe we’ll even see some ice breaking! 

One of the group is currently undergoing treatment for bowel cancer, while the others’ lives have been touched by cancer in many different ways.

Macmillan support those with cancer from the moment they’re diagnosed, through treatment and beyond, offering emotional, physical and financial support.

The aim of the challenge will be to be in cold water for at least one minute every day, although some will do so for longer spells. Updates, videos and photos will be posted on this page. 

Those undertaking the open water dunks are our more-experienced group members and are doing so at their own risk. Please give generously for this good cause.

The Nippy Dippers are Chris Jenkins, Kenny MacLean, Andy Begg, Jack Calvert, Ewan Johnstone and Bill Martin.

Thank you for checking out my Just Giving Page.

My name is Lowri Parsons and I am 16 years old. And I am a volunteer for Macmillan Cancer Support and I have been since I was 9 years old when my grandad was diagnosed with cancer. In 2017 I was awarded the Young Macmillan Champion Fundraiser award and then I was also awarded it again in 2019. 

Usually throughout the year I would be doing loads of fundraising but because of coronavirus I have been very limited to what I have been able to do. Previously in the year I did Lowri's Long Walk Through Lockdown, where I walked 5km everyday and raised over £500. I would love to be able to raise some more money for the people who need it.

So I decided this time that what I would do to fundraise would be to upload a video everyday of me either singing a Christmas song, or me playing a Christmas song on the piano. I will be uploading the videos from the 1st December until 25th December.

I would really appreciate it if you could donate to my page and share my story so that I can raise money for those people who really need it through these hard times.

Thank you, Merry Christmas x

story:
Last month I had a call from my mum with the sort of news that everyone dreads. She'd noticed that the tips of her fingers had become quite sensitive and sore, and her nails had started to clump. A similar thing happened to my auntie a couple of years ago, and it turned out to be lung cancer, so my mum went straight to her GP for some answers. After a series of tests and pokes of a needle, it was confirmed that she does in fact have stage 3 lung cancer. This year has been tough for everyone, for many different reasons, and not being able to see her due to covid was hard enough without this adding to it. Luckily for her it's treatable, and she's hopefully due surgery very soon. She'll be without the majority of her right lung, and there's a long road to recovery ahead, but she's going to be okay. That's the best news anyone could ever tell you.

But I know that not everyone is that lucky. Not everyone is told that they're going to be okay, or that their loved ones are going to recover. So this is why I have chosen to do a charity stream for Macmillan Cancer Support. They're there for so many people that are living with cancer, going through treatments, and trying to live the best life that they possibly can. I am so grateful for all the support they give, all the fundraising they do, and what they stand for.

For more information about this wonderful organisation, visit the website;

https://www.macmillan.org.uk

I am going to be doing a charity stream on Twitch on December 13th from 7pm. Joined by some wonderful friends of mine to play games and raise some money. Any donations would be hugely appreciated, no matter how small.

Here's the link to my Twitch channel;

Twitch.tv/Fi3ryRedHe4d94

Thank you x

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We want to raise this money in memory of David Farrand, who sadly passed away on Saturday 28th November 2020. It is traditional to have a funeral service and send flowers when someone close to us dies but David was not a traditional kind of guy! It is for this reason that we have chosen to remember him in a different way. He wanted instead for people to donate what they might have spent on flowers to a charity that was close to his heart. The chosen charity is the British Heart Foundation.

David was an amazing husband, son, brother and friend. He was an unbelievable father and the most incredible grandpa. He was the silliest of souls and a true gentleman, who touched the hearts of everyone who met him. 

After flowers would have long-wilted, David’s alternative choice will ensure that his memory lives on and makes a positive difference to the lives of others.

We thank you on David’s behalf for your donations.

Amanda, Kim and Laura

story:
Hi, we are Grace, Jake and Holly and we are taking part in a virtual rowing challenge to raise funds for British Heart Foundation, a charity close to our hearts.

Our challenge is to row the length of the River Severn in just under 24 days on a static rowing machine.

We will be Ready to Row on 1 December and our challenge is to be back home in time to hang our stockings up for Santa on Christmas Eve!

The River Severn is the longest river in the United Kingdom measuring in at 354km long, so that means we will need to maintain a steady 5km a day each for just over 23 days (if Holly's arithmetic is right this time...ask us about her River Nile calculations, it's a very funny story!)

If you would like to join us on this incredible journey - all we ask is that you make a donation to our JustGiving page and then sit back and make yourself comfortable whilst we take you on the row of a lifetime, charting our progress over some of the UK's special rivers along the way.

Thanks again for visiting our page.  The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help us reach (or, better yet, exceed!) our target.

story:
As most of you will know by now, 2019 was the beginning of very challenging time for the team at Una Rodden.  The shock cancer diagnosis of our friend and esteemed colleague, Monica, turned all of our worlds upside down, none more so than Monica herself, who faced a tumultuous year of illness.  Undoubtedly, Monica's strength of mind and positivity pulled her through every hurdle, but without the knowledge and care of the medical profession, this would not have been possible. 

The statistics now show that 1 in 2 will face cancer in their lifetime.  We all feel so thankful that Monica has come out the other side and are keen to support further research into finding a cure for this devastating disease. 

In spite of reduced dexterity and sensitivity in her hands due to the chemotherapy, Monica has kept herself busy with crocheting.  This particular blanket has been made to raffle for Cancer Research UK, using ends of wool for sustainability and creating a patchwork effect to represent the myriad stories of cancer, which have impacted the lives of so many.

To be in with a chance of getting your hands on this masterpiece in time for Christmas, simply make a donation.  We will allocate a ballot number with your name for every £1 spent.  The raffle will run for 2 weeks, ending on 15th Dec, at which time, we will randomly select the winning number, who will then be contacted for delivery details. 

We really appreciate your support for this amazing cause.  Thank you and best of luck!

story:
In the words of our founder Max.....



"This group was never about trade in the economic sense. It was always about humanity and it was always about love. And it was also about understanding that music is an *essential* element of our being human. We have every reason to think that communities have been singing, playing, drumming and dancing together for hundreds of thousands of years, with every song and beat binding people together, literally creating and perpetuating harmony across our planet.

In our modern world, and contrary to all our instincts, we have commodified our artistic output and although we have created great art, high and low, in the process, we have also forgotten that music belongs to us all. If you have ever felt like expressing yourself artistically but stopped because you felt that your art was not worthy, the Viral Jukebox is your home. I mean it.

More than once since I created this group people have suggested that I could find a way to monetise it. They are missing the point. The currency here is love. Spend freely. Give freely. And remember, if you sang or played it from your heart, you played it right."

So this Christmas, with the Pandemic rolling on and weird hybrid lockdown in place, we thought it would be great to raise money, together, for our favourite causes, so choose the one closest to your heart (or follow the person who made a song you like and vote for a cause they love!)

Happy Christmas Jukeboxers!



.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit this page where I'm fundraising in memory of my mum, Jo Ann McLaughlin. When she first became ill (and beat cancer in her first brave battle) she had a round of radiotherapy and I sent her a song a day to listen to during the treatment, which she said kept her smiling throughout. This is why I'm reviving the 'musical advent', as I know it's something my mum would love, to raise money for Cancer Research.

Since losing her I've been too sad, too angry and a bit of a mess so I never wrote or posted this anywhere:

On Monday 17th August of this year my Mum died surrounded by the loving family her and my Dad created.

This woman showed me how to be a loving son, brother, husband, father and friend. I cannot put into words how I have felt since the loss of such a kind, caring and loving person. She dedicated her whole life both professionally and personally to helping people feel better about themselves. I didn't tell her enough what a true inspiration she was. Nor did I spend enough time trying to make her happier when she needed it.

Since that morning I have been overwhelmed by the love and support from a number of friends and family who have told me what my mum meant and represented to them. The consistent themes of happiness, positivity, humility, empathy and fun have been repeated in all the messages I've received.

She was a beautiful human being in every sense of the word and I'm going to make sure her spark and spirit live on through the stories and lessons I pass down to Martha who I'm so glad mum got chance to meet.

I know 2020 has hit people hard so I'm only asking you to donate if you can afford to - any small amount will help keep me strumming my four chord disasters!

James x

Jude was an incredibly warm and caring friend to many, and a real tough cookie. When faced with adversity in her personal or work life, she was a force to be reckoned with, a real fighter.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Diane Chambers
story:
Turn your attention away from me as an ugly baby and instead to the women on the left, my Grandma, Diane Chambers. On 27th July 2020 she sadly lost her fight to terminal brain cancer. Currently due to COVID people like my Grandma are suffering from terminal illnesses alone, with little access to their loved ones to alleviate their struggles. Nurses are doing everything they can in these unmanageable times, but the truth is with little support and underfunding, the NHS cannot provide the care patients desperately require.

The light of this story is the care my Grandma received once in palliative care in her own home. Regardless of her months of turmoil, a nurse named Jovie was able to bring comfort and happiness to my Grandmas last days, providing physical and emotional care. Jovie demonstrated that people living with terminal illnesses can still have a quality life, and I would like to ensure others get the same experience. 

That being said, on the 19th December 2020, I will be challenging myself to complete a back to back triple marathon. This involves a 26 mile ski, 26 mile bike, finished with a 26 mile run, totalling 78 miles. My goal is to raise at least £1000 for Marie Curie just in time for Christmas. My employers Vanquis Bank have generously offered to double all donations up to £500 meaning your donation will go twice as far.

Marie Curie is a company who care and support people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Their nurses work night and day in people’s homes and their hospices offer specialist care. They also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers. Below is the impact this money could have:

  • As little as £20 can fund an hour of nursing care for someone with terminal illness in their home.
  • £70 pays for someone with a terminal illness to attend a day therapy at a Marie Curie Hospice, benefitting from gentle exercise, an art class and more.
  • £180 will pay for a Marie Curie nurse to look after someone with a terminal illness for a full nine-hour shift.
  • £400 pays for someone to stay in a Marie Curie hospice for 24 hours, so they can receive the hands-on care they need in
    their days.
  • £5,500 will cover the cost of Marie Curies entire nursing service across the UK for one hour.
  • £19,000 will pay for a year of care from a Marie Curie nurse for people with a terminal illness.

Any donations no matter the amount are accepted, they all make a difference!

Thanks for you for reading and wish me luck!

story:
Our hospice is a warm and welcoming place, supporting people in Edinburgh and their loved ones with expert care, every day of the year. 

Our doctors, nurses, physiotherapists and social workers are supported by a team of volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice.

Some of the people we support stay in our in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night and stay with their loved ones if they wish to.

We also support local people with clinics, therapies and activities during the day  including one-to-one care, groups and things like reiki and massage. 

As well as people with a terminal illness, we also support carers and families with things like bereavement support groups where people can share their experiences and feelings.

Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Edinburgh get the care and support they need.

In 2015 our beautiful Craig was given the devastating news he had terminal cancer. Just 3 weeks after diagnosis the time came for Craig to be cared for at Marie Curie Holme Tower hospice. None of us knew what to expect and  the unknown was frightening and overwhelming. However, the staff were  exceptional, caring for Craig and all of us. They made it possible for the hospice to become our home for over 2 weeks. We were able to celebrate Craig's 26th birthday whilst we were there. We will be eternally grateful to the amazing staff for providing us with the the opportunity to make the most of the precious time we had left together. As  a way of honouring Craig  and showing our gratitude to the amazing staff we're hoping to raise enough money to pay for a day at Marie Curie Holme Tower hospice which will be commemorated by a plaque in Craig's name. It's costs a staggering £6660 to run the hospice for 1 day, we were fortunate to have 16 days with Craig in the hospice.  Any support would be really appreciated. 

Your support will provide other families with the same exceptionl care Craig and all of us received. Anything you can spare is hugely appreciated.

story:
The RNLI have had an incredibly hard year, they have managed to carry on saving lives at sea despite Covid-19, with lifeboat volunteers still rescuing those in danger, putting their lives even more at risk, as it was impossible to isolate from other volunteers and casualties.

Unfortunately, Lifeboat days, cake sales and a lot of other fundraising opportunities have had to be cancelled due to Covid, dramatically reducing the income of the RNLI during these difficult times. The RNLI has 238 lifeboat stations and operates 444 lifeboats, with around 5,600 lifeboat volunteers (from all walks of life, not just those involved in maritime work). Crews rescue on average 22 people a day.

We have raised funds for the RNLI in the past by busking and asking for donations instead of birthday presents. However, as it has not been possible to busk or hold birthday parties this year, we would like to ask people to donate any amount (no matter how small) towards this amazing charity. In return, each day we will be uploading a musical performance.

Also, please watch “Saving Lives at Sea” on BBC2 to see some of the amazing work that the RNLI carry out every day of the year (they are even on call on Christmas Day).

Our aim for this term was to create a showcase for this work to display to our wider school community and, as we are not able to welcome you into our school for this in person, each class have created an iMovie to show off and display the amazing work which they have created. We have done this with the aim of raising money for the World Wildlife Fund. Week 1: Total of 500x skips (100 skips per day)

Week 2: Total of 1,000x skips (200 skips per day)

Week 3: Total of 1,500x skips (300 skips per day)

Week 4: Total of 2,000x skips (400 skips per day)

story:
2020 has been an uncertain year for us all. One thing we have been able to rely on here in the UK is clean water.

Not in Ethiopia. You can contribute to a Future On Tap.

With clean water, people will be healthier and able to grow fruit and vegetables in kitchen gardens, so they can have nutritious food whatever the weather.

Children will have more time to go to school, to have fun and to pursue their dreams, free from the burden of collecting dirty water every day.

The day clean water arrives will mark the beginning of their brightest chapter, giving everyone the chance to thrive and rewrite the rest of their story.

Future on Tap contributes to reaching Sustainable Development Goals 6 and 13 by providing climate-resilient water and sanitation to climate-vulnerable communities.

Each donation before 4 February 2021 will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. 

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.
